question_details.title: Will Walmart have a higher market cap than Tesla on March 29, 2025?
question_details.description: Business Insider: [Tesla's latest decline could be one for the history books, JPMorgan analysts say](https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-stock-decline-jp-morgan-analyst-guidance-2025-3)
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if Walmart has a higher market capitalization than Tesla after the close of trading on March 29, 2025, according to [CompaniesMarketCap](https://companiesmarketcap.com/)

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Best Retail Stocks To Keep An Eye On - March 16th**
MarketBeat's stock screener tool has identified Tesla, Apple, Microsoft, Amazon.com, and Walmart as the top retail stocks to watch today. These companies have the highest dollar trading volume of any retail stocks within the last several days. Tesla's stock traded up $9.30 on Friday, reaching $249.98, while Apple's stock traded up $3.81, reaching $213.49. Microsoft's stock traded up $9.79, hitting $388.56, and Amazon.com's stock traded up $4.06, hitting $197.95. Walmart's stock traded up $0.79, hitting $85.29. The companies have strong market capitalizations, with Tesla at $804.06 billion, Apple at $3.21 trillion, Microsoft at $2.89 trillion, Amazon.com at $2.10 trillion, and Walmart at $685.19 billion.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 18, 2025 06:38 AM
Source:[Defense World](https://www.defenseworld.net/2025/03/18/best-retail-stocks-to-keep-an-eye-on-march-16th.html)

**US Stock Market Continues Upward Trend on Improved Retail Sales and Chinese Economic Policies**
The US stock market continued its upward trend on March 17, with the Dow Jones rising by 353.44 dollars to 41,841.63 dollars and the Nasdaq rising by 54.57 points to 17,808.66. Despite retail sales falling short of expectations, the market showed resilience and rebounded. The Dow Jones was boosted by improved Chinese retail sales and reports that the Chinese government is planning to implement policies to support consumption. The Nasdaq was influenced by the keynote speech of NVIDIA's CEO at the gtc 2025 developer conference, as well as expectations of a rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The market saw a surge in the final trading session, with the Dow Jones and Nasdaq both closing at their highs. Sector-wise, real estate management and development, and food and household goods retail saw gains, while automobiles and automotive parts saw losses. PepsiCo rose after announcing the acquisition of functional soda brand 'Poppies'. Lululemon Athletica, Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings, and Netflix rose due to analysts' upgraded investment recommendations. Affirm fell after announcing that Swedish fintech company Klarna would replace it as the exclusive provider of its buy-now-pay-later service to Walmart. Walmart rose. Robinhood rose due to expectations of increased revenue following the launch of a new platform for predicting sports, politics, and Federal Open Market Committee results. Tesla fell due to analysts' downward revisions to their target stock price. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated in a TV interview over the weekend that there is no guarantee that the economy will avoid a recession. 
Original language: ja
Publish date: March 17, 2025 11:17 PM
Source:[財経新聞](https://www.zaikei.co.jp/article/20250318/804198.html)

**Trump: Xi Jinping to Visit US in the Near Future**
US President Donald Trump stated that Chinese leader Xi Jinping will visit the US in the 'not too distant future'. According to Reuters. The New York stock exchange showed a positive trend after four brutal weeks, with rising stock prices for the second consecutive trading day. Traders on Wall Street chose to be optimistic and interpreted Monday's news positively. One of the factors was that US retail sales increased by 0.2% in February compared to January, which was significantly lower than some expectations of a 0.6% increase. However, excluding car sales, the increase was 0.3%, which was in line with expectations. Companies such as Walmart and IBM saw significant gains, with increases of 2.5% and 1.9% respectively. Tesla continued its downward trend, falling 4.8%. The company has fallen 40.7% since the start of the year. Factors that have contributed to the uncertainty include President Trump's confusing tariff announcement, a weakening labor market, recession warnings, decreased economic confidence among American households, rising inflation, and global security uncertainty.

**S&P 500 Rallies Today Despite Economic Growth Concerns**
The S&P 500 (SPX) is up 0.42% today despite concerns over slowing economic growth and increased inflation, as warned by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in its latest report. The OECD expects U.S. annual GDP growth to fall from 2.8% in 2024 to 1.6% in 2026, and U.S. inflation to increase from 2.5% in 2024 to 2.6% in 2026. The SPX has dropped 3.97% over the last three months and 4.13% year-to-date, but is currently performing well, with the consumer defensive sector leading the way. Stocks such as Walmart (WMT) and Pepsi (PEP) are seeing large increases, while Tesla (TSLA) is experiencing a 4.06% drop. Investors can consider buying shares listed on the SPX, such as consumer staples stocks, or investing in stocks falling today if they expect a rebound.

**China Market Update: Local Carmakers Beat Out Tesla As Sales Surge In February, Xpeng Says Flying Cars Possible By 2026**
China's markets were little changed, with some computing-related stocks rising ahead of an AI conference in Hangzhou. Automakers extended gains after wholesale vehicle sales increased 34.4% year over year in February, with Tesla accounting for only 5% of sales. Xpeng said it could have its first flying car models available as soon as next year. Mainland investors purchased a net $3.4 billion worth of Hong Kong-listed stocks and ETFs, with Materials, Utilities, and Energy being the top-performing sectors. The Hang Seng and Hang Seng Tech indexes closed lower by -0.76% and -2.04%, respectively, with Information Technology, Consumer Staples, and Health Care being the worst-performing sectors. Shanghai, Shenzhen, and the STAR Board diverged in their closing prices, with Communication Services, Financials, and Utilities being the top-performing sectors. The Chinese government has successfully complied with all applicable international drug control obligations and is ready to return to dialogue on drug control. Walmart has asked its China-based suppliers to lower their prices in response to tariffs, and the Ministry of Commerce (MoC) is holding talks with Walmart on its demands.

**Bitcoin and Stock Market Decline Since Trump's Re-election: What's Behind the Drop?**
The cryptocurrency market and stock market have been declining since Donald Trump's re-election. Bitcoin, which had reached an all-time high of $108,786 on the day of Trump's inauguration, has since dropped by 25%. The decline is attributed to investors selling their positions in riskier assets, such as crypto, and moving to safer investments like government bonds. The yield on 10-year US Treasury bonds has fallen to 4.29%, indicating that investors are shifting their capital to less risky assets. The VIX-index, a measure of market anxiety, has risen to its highest point this year, while Walmart, a key indicator of the US economy, has warned that its expected revenue growth in 2025 will be lower than previously forecast. This has fueled anxiety and uncertainty among investors. Technology stocks, which had driven the market up in 2024, are now showing weakness, with companies like Nvidia, Palantir, and Tesla leading the decline. Meanwhile, European and Chinese markets are performing well, with the STOXX 600 index up nearly 10% this year and Chinese tech stocks rising by over 35% since January. Despite the recent corrections, the Dow Jones and S&P 500 are still higher than they were at Trump's re-election in November. However, the question remains whether the upward trend of 2023 and 2024 can be sustained in 2025, with many investors believing the market is overvalued.
Original language: nl
Publish date: February 27, 2025 09:05 PM
Source:[crypto-insiders.nl](https://www.crypto-insiders.nl/nieuws/bitcoin/bitcoin-en-aandelenmarkt-kelderen-sinds-trumps-rentree-hoe-komt-dit/)

**Investors need to 'bring an umbrella' for rainy days ahead**
US stocks are trading lower at the end of a volatile week. Keith Gangl, portfolio manager at Gradient Investments, advises investors to 'bring an umbrella' for potential corrections in 2025. He expects a 5-10% pullback and recommends holding onto the 'Magnificent Seven' stocks, excluding Tesla, as well as healthcare and industrial sectors, and specific companies like Netflix, Dexcom, Palo Alto Networks, and Walmart. Gangl believes the market will experience a normalized return, but warns of corrections along the way.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 24, 2025 11:00 AM
Source:[Yahoo! Finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/video/investors-bring-umbrella-rainy-days-110004307.html)

**Why the US Stock Market is 'Expensive' and Vulnerable**
Aaron Lanni, a portfolio manager at Medici, advises investors to look beyond the absolute price of a stock and consider the profit per share. He cites the example of Walmart, whose stock price is around $100 USD, but has a profit per share of $2.67 USD, resulting in a high multiple of 35 times earnings. In contrast, Booking's stock price is around $5000 USD, but has a profit per share of $209 USD in 2025, resulting in a multiple of 24 times earnings. Frédéric L'Heureux, a portfolio manager at Valeurs mobilières Desjardins, notes that the US market is 'expensive' and vulnerable due to high expectations of profit growth and a list of unaccounted risks, including inflation, economic deceleration, and geopolitical tensions. He also warns that the current multiple of 22 times earnings for the S&P 500 is higher than its historical average of 16.7 times, indicating a 30% premium. 'It has reached levels higher than 22 times only twice since 1996 (during the tech bubble and the pandemic),' says Frédéric L'Heureux. 'Tesla is valued at 115 times its profits because there is a lot of enthusiasm for artificial intelligence and what it means for this company,' he adds. 'More than 80% of the value attributed to Tesla by investors is due to products that are not yet commercialized, such as autonomous vehicles and humanoid robots.' 
Original language: fr
Publish date: February 23, 2025 10:00 AM
Source:[La Presse.ca](https://www.lapresse.ca/affaires/marches/cher-le-marche-boursier-pourquoi-donc/2025-02-23/le-ratio-cours-benefice-comme-guide.php)

**Tesla's Struggles with Electric Car Sales and Musk's Bet on AI and Robotics**
Tesla's automotive division has faced its lowest profitability in five years, with a 13.6% gross margin in the fourth quarter of 2024, down from 20-30% in 2020. The company has been actively selling cars at the end of 2024, lowering prices to get rid of excess inventory. However, investors are skeptical that this will help the company in the long term. Despite this, Tesla's stock has risen, with investors focusing on the company's development of artificial intelligence and robotics. Elon Musk has made a bet on these areas, announcing the launch of Tesla Robotaxi in June 2025 and the production of 100 million Optimus robots by 2026. Musk expects the robot market to be worth trillions of dollars, with the Optimus robot alone potentially generating more revenue than Walmart's annual income. However, some investors are concerned that Tesla is losing ground in the electric car market and facing serious problems in its core business.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 01, 2025 02:26 PM
Source:[Pravda](https://www.pravda.ru/news/auto/2170386-tesla_profit/)

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To establish a base rate, I will refer to the historical market caps of Walmart and Tesla over the last several years. Historically, Tesla has experienced volatile market valuations often influenced by technological advancements, regulatory news, and market speculation. In contrast, Walmart's market cap has been relatively more stable due to its consistent revenue streams from retail operations. As of late 2024, Tesla's market cap was noticeably higher than Walmart's—with Tesla often ranking among the top 10 while Walmart was within the top 20 by market cap globally. Considering these historical trends, the base rate for Walmart's market cap surpassing Tesla's by the target date is approximately 25%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Tesla market decline
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Tesla has recently faced notable declines in stock value, partly due to regulatory changes, increased competition in the EV sector, and supply chain issues, which could significantly impact its market cap.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Steady performance of Walmart
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Walmart's consistent business model and expansion in e-commerce make it less sensitive to market volatility compared to high-growth tech companies like Tesla. This stability can be favorable when competitors face market declines.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Economic indicators and inflation impact
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: 2025 has seen inflationary pressures, which might shift investor preference towards companies with stable cash flows like Walmart over high-growth but volatile companies like Tesla.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Technological innovations at Tesla
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Any unexpected or significant technological innovations from Tesla before the forecast date could boost investor confidence, potentially increasing Tesla's stock value.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several news articles indicate that Tesla's stock has been consistently falling, with a 40.7% decline since the start of the year, and further drops noted in recent trading sessions. Additionally, the automotive sector faced losses, and analysts have revised Tesla's target stock price downward. Conversely, Walmart has been gaining, influenced by increases in certain retail sales segments and expectations of increased revenue. Consumer staples, where Walmart is a dominant player, have also been performing well in the current economic climate.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Tesla is working on producing a lower-cost Model Y in Shanghai, which could regain it some market share. Despite its struggles, Tesla's involvement in AI and robotics continues to maintain some investor interest. The US stock market overall is on an upward trend, which might offset some negative sentiment around Tesla.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, both Tesla and Walmart have been among the largest companies globally by market capitalization. Tesla has experienced significant volatility in its stock price, leading to fluctuations in its market cap. Whereas Walmart's market cap tends to be more stable. Historically, Tesla's market cap surpassed Walmart's in periods of rapid growth in the EV market and speculative bubbles. Based on historical data, Tesla and Walmart have taken turns in surpassing each other in market cap within the past few years, making the initial base rate of either company having a higher market cap approximately even at 50%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Decline in Tesla's Stock Price
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The decline in Tesla's stock price as reported by analysts is a notable factor. This decline reduces Tesla's market cap relative to Walmart's more stable value, increasing the likelihood that Walmart will surpass Tesla in market cap.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Stability of Walmart's Market Cap
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Walmart's market cap is historically stable due to its mature business model and consistent revenue streams. This stability makes it less susceptible to the market fluctuations currently affecting Tesla, further increasing the probability that Walmart's market cap will exceed Tesla's.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Economic Impact on Consumer Spending
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The economic climate can influence consumer spending, which directly affects Walmart's revenue given its retail business model. A strong economic climate supports Walmart's high market cap, reinforcing its stability.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Tesla's stock has continued to decline, with the latest reports showing further drops amid analysts' downward revisions to Tesla's target stock price. Tesla's market cap is affected negatively as its shares fell, reinforcing the likelihood of Walmart having a higher market cap.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite Tesla's challenges, the company is advancing in AI and robotics, which have historically driven speculative interest and investment, that could potentially counterbalance or support its market cap. Nonetheless, the immediate impact of these developments on market perception before March 29, 2025, seems limited.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To estimate the initial probability of Walmart having a higher market cap than Tesla on March 29, 2025, I will first consider historical data on the sizes of both companies. Historically, Walmart has had a large and relatively stable market capitalization due to its established position in the retail sector. Tesla, in contrast, has exhibited more volatility, with periods of rapid growth and occasional declines in its market cap. Based on this, let's consider the historical base rate as the percentage of times Walmart has had a higher market cap than Tesla in the last five years. A review of historical data suggests that Walmart has occasionally surpassed Tesla in market cap, particularly during periods of market correction or downward pressure on Tesla's stock. Given this historical context, I estimate the base rate probability of Walmart surpassing Tesla in market cap as approximately 30%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Tesla's Recent Stock Decline
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The recent decline in Tesla's stock, as highlighted by JPMorgan, suggests that Tesla's market cap is likely under downward pressure. This increase in volatility and potential downward trend makes it more plausible that Walmart could surpass Tesla's market cap.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Walmart's Stability and Earnings Potential
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Walmart's market cap is driven by its stable earnings and large consumer base. Despite market fluctuations, it has historically maintained robust numbers, and any improvement in its performance or market sentiment could support a higher valuation.

perspective_derived_factors.name: General Market Conditions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Current market conditions, with potential geopolitical uncertainties or economic factors, could influence investor sentiment. If investor sentiment turns risk-averse, Tesla's higher-risk profile compared to Walmart's more stable profile might lead to a relative increase in Walmart's market cap compared to Tesla’s.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several news articles indicate Tesla's continued stock decline, with reports stating it is down 40.7% since the start of the year. Analysts have revised Tesla's stock price target downward, contributing to its negative trend. Additionally, Tesla faces challenges with profitability in its core automotive division and pressures from local competitors in China. Furthermore, economic uncertainty and mixed signals from key market indicators provide a risk-averse environment that might benefit Walmart's stability.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite negative trends, Tesla still maintains a significant market cap, and its innovations in AI and robotics remain points of investor interest, though speculative. The US stock market's overall upward trend and the positive sentiment from US-China relations could potentially provide Tesla some recovery.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, Tesla and Walmart have both been among the largest companies by market capitalization, with fluctuations in their respective rankings based on broader market trends, company performance, and economic conditions. Walmart has traditionally had a relatively stable market cap compared to Tesla, which can experience significant volatility due to market sentiment around technology companies, particularly in the electric vehicle sector. Historically, in recent years, Tesla's market cap has been higher than Walmart's at certain times due to the high valuation multiples driven by its growth prospects. Given the historical data, a reasonable starting point for whether Walmart could surpass Tesla's market cap would be around 40%, factoring in Tesla's historical volatility and potential for a downturn.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Tesla's Recent Volatility
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Tesla's stock has been noted for its volatility. The recent decline reported by JPMorgan suggests a potential continuation of this trend, which might affect its market cap negatively relative to Walmart's stable valuation.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Economic Conditions Impacting Technology Stocks
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Given the prevailing economic conditions in 2025, with potential interest rate hikes and inflation concerns, technology stocks like Tesla may face downward pressure. This could make it more feasible for Walmart's stable market cap to surpass Tesla's.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Walmart's Earnings Stability
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Walmart's earnings tend to be more stable and less prone to large fluctuations compared to a tech company like Tesla. This stability is appealing during uncertain economic times, potentially enhancing investors' confidence in Walmart, thereby increasing its market cap.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Historical Market Caps
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Historically, Tesla has leveraged its market narrative and growth potential to maintain a high market cap. While declines occur, its large cap status is usually regained due to strong investor sentiment toward tech stocks.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Market Correction Likelihood
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There is the possibility of a broader market correction affecting high-growth stocks that have surged in valuation without commensurate earnings growth. This potential correction might disproportionately impact companies like Tesla.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Tesla has been experiencing significant stock price declines, as shown by multiple reports indicating drops of up to 50% from its all-time high and a continued downward trend. Analysts have downgraded target prices for Tesla, and there is noted volatility in the tech sector. Meanwhile, Walmart, though experiencing some pressure from trade dynamics, has seen stable or rising stock prices as part of the consumer defensive sector, which benefits during economic uncertainty.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite the decline in Tesla's stock, there is enthusiasm for Tesla's long-term prospects tied to AI and robotics, which investors are betting on heavily. This could counterbalance some of the immediate volatility in their market cap by retaining optimistic market sentiment.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To establish a base rate, we look at the historical occurrence of Walmart surpassing Tesla in market capitalization. Historically, Walmart has had a more stable market cap, being a retail giant with consistent revenue streams, while Tesla's market cap has been more volatile due to its dependence on innovation and market sentiment. The frequency of Walmart surpassing Tesla's market cap has been relatively low in recent years, though the volatility of Tesla suggests the possibility of significant changes. Therefore, I set an initial probability of 25% for Walmart having a higher market cap than Tesla on the given date.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Tesla's Recent Decline
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The recent decline in Tesla's stock value as noted in the Business Insider article suggests a decrease in market confidence in Tesla. This can result in a further decline in Tesla's market cap, increasing the likelihood that Walmart might have a higher market cap by the resolution date.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Walmart's Stability
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Walmart's financial stability and consistent performance suggest it is less likely to experience significant market cap volatility. This stability provides a relatively secure baseline for its current market cap.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Macro-economic Factors
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: A positive or negative shift in macroeconomic factors such as consumer spending and inflation can affect both companies. Given the current economic conditions, a potential downturn or recession might lower spending on Tesla's high-ticket items while boosting or stabilizing Walmart's sales of essentials.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Recent articles indicate a continued decline in Tesla's stock price due to downward revisions in target stock prices, lower than expected electric car sales, and increased competition in China. Additionally, Tesla's current market cap is reported at $804.06 billion, while Walmart's is at $685.19 billion, with Tesla continuing to experience a downward trend in share price. This situation reinforces the possibility of Walmart surpassing Tesla.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: However, Tesla's efforts to innovate in AI and robotics could attract investor optimism despite its current struggles, which may stabilize or increase its market cap. Additionally, the general upward trend in the U.S. stock market may temper losses across tech stocks.

summary: In the initial phase, experts analyzed historical market cap trends and current economic factors, assigning probabilities for Walmart surpassing Tesla in market cap by March 29, 2025. Probabilities ranged from 15% to 70%, with factors such as Tesla's stock volatility, Walmart's stable growth, and economic conditions influencing forecasts. In the second phase, after reviewing recent news of Tesla's stock decline and Walmart's stable performance, all experts increased their probabilities. The revised probabilities for Walmart having a higher market cap than Tesla ranged from 30% to 75%, reflecting reinforced confidence due to Tesla's ongoing stock struggles and the resilience of Walmart's market position.
